reviews.text: It isn’t nonstop hilarity; there are quite a few dead spots. But I liked it a lot.
reviews.author: Rob Gonsalves

reviews.text: The teaming and the formula are often copied but rarely matched.
reviews.author: Mike Massie

reviews.text: What makes this fantasy of anti-social behaviour so painfully funny, is the gulf between etiquette and vulgarity, the desire to be a child whooping it up in the adult world.
reviews.author: Ryan Gilbey

reviews.text: You cannot deny a laugh, and Dumb and Dumber has plenty.
reviews.author: Gene Siskel

reviews.text: ...a modern classic of the comedy genre...
reviews.author: David Nusair

reviews.text: The plot, of course, is merely an excuse for an endless series of gags, and the percentage of them that score is fairly high.
reviews.author: Frank Scheck

reviews.text: From the puns to the slapstick to the toilet, Dumb and Dumber is performed at such a high level that it transcends many of its influences.
reviews.author: Bill Clark

reviews.text: Easily one of the funniest (and most quotable) movies ever made...
reviews.author: Felix Vasquez Jr.

reviews.text: The caviar of low-brow, gross-out comedy.
reviews.author: Scott G. Mignola

reviews.text: The Farrellys' knack for stupid, Three Stooges-esque comedy writ larger by an infusion of heart excels with the complementary screen teaming of manic Jim Carrey and consummate screen actor Jeff Daniels. [Blu-ray]
reviews.author: Peter Canavese

reviews.text: ...it tickles the funny bone often enough to merit serious consideration among lowbrow comedies.
reviews.author: John J. Puccio

reviews.text: [Featrues] a plethora of memorable scenes.
reviews.author: Mark Dinning

reviews.text: Dumb and Dumber, which features Carrey and Jeff Daniels as nitwits traveling cross-country, is a frayed string of gags posing as a movie. Carrey, though, does literal-minded doofdom with peerless enthusiasm.
reviews.author: Owen Gleiberman

reviews.text: This gleefully lowbrow film is best enjoyed by the young, and by those who can still laugh at the passing of gas.
The wholeheartedness of this descent into crude and rude humor is so good-natured and precise that it's hard not to partake in the guilty pleasures of the exercise.
reviews.author: Variety Staff

reviews.text: This is a long way from the social comedy of Jerry Lewis. The characters here are ultimately turned into punching bags or punch-line dispensers.
reviews.author: Jonathan Rosenbaum

reviews.text: Well titled and, for its purpose, a total success.
reviews.author: Steve Crum

reviews.text: Gone are the days of John Belushi, where rudeness was raised to an art form.
reviews.author: Jeffrey M. Anderson

reviews.text: Given American cinema's current obsession with innocence and ignorance, at least this never romanticises its protagonists. They are genuinely, irredeemably, 100 per cent no-hopers.
reviews.author: Tom Charity

reviews.text: A gross-out classic.
reviews.author: Kevin Carr

reviews.text: we can see a lot of these laughs coming, and they don't hold much staying power
reviews.author: Chris Cabin

reviews.text: The 'limo'driver' line made the rest of the movie worth the trouble.
reviews.author: Gregory Weinkauf

reviews.text: a bit too dumb
reviews.author: Rich Cline

reviews.text: The funniest movie in the world.
reviews.author: Phil Villarreal

reviews.text: Released before I started reviewing, but I would be remiss if I didn't say: it's a fine film. Had me buckling over in laughter, often, little plot, 100% pure stupid genius.
reviews.author: Ross Anthony

reviews.text: A movie that fully lives up to its name, right down to an opening credit sequence rife with intentional misspellings and grammatical errors.
reviews.author: Stephen Holden

reviews.text: The title says it all
reviews.author: Ken Hanke

reviews.text: Dumb, but funny. Very funny.
reviews.author: Mike McGranaghan

reviews.text: Despretensiosamente ingnuo, 'Dbi & Lide'  a maior prova de que um filme nem sempre precisa ter uma trama elaborada para agradar.
reviews.author: Pablo Villaça

reviews.text: Inspired, irreverent, spark-driven comedy that takes you places you never thought a movie would go -- even a Jim Carrey movie.
reviews.author: Peter Stack

reviews.text: Carrey, I am now convinced, is a true original. In The Mask, he had the screenplay and production to back him up. Here, the filmmaking is more uncertain.
reviews.author: Roger Ebert

reviews.text: Farrelly, quite simply put, does not appear to have the slightest clue about comic timing.
reviews.author: Scott Renshaw

reviews.text: An execrable catalogue of doody jokes, Dumb and Dumber is an abominable, abdominal comedy.
reviews.author: Rita Kempley

reviews.text: Maybe it's indicative of my end-of-the-year brain-fry, but this dopey comedy about two of the dumbest guys in the universe on a road trip to misadventure is a hoot.
reviews.author: Marjorie Baumgarten

reviews.text: While I won't claim to have gone through this entire film without laughing, there are some long periods between chuckles.
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: This virtually laughless movie makes rude junior high school pranks seem positively sophisticated.
reviews.author: Chris Hicks

reviews.text: An uneven collection of bodily function jokes, facial gyrations, sexual jibes and pedestrian slapstick.
reviews.author: Desson Thomson

synopsis: Imbecilic best friends Lloyd Christmas (Jim Carrey) and Harry Dunne (Jeff Daniels) stumble across a suitcase full of money left behind in Harry's car by Mary Swanson (Lauren Holly), who was on her way to the airport. The pair decide to go to Aspen, Colo., to return the money, unaware that it is connected to a kidnapping. As Harry and Lloyd -- who has fallen in love with Mary -- are pursued across the country by hired killers and police, they find both their friendship and their brains tested.
